title-group.article-title: The Journal of School Nursing-SAGE Writing Awards

contrib.aff: Executive Editor, The Journal of School Nursing

body.p: The Journal of School Nursing (JOSN) and SAGE Publications present two writing awards to promote publishing that contributes to school nursing practice and to recognize excellence in writing. The Executive Editor of The Journal and the Editorial Advisory Board selected recipients. Papers published in the February through December issues of 2011 were considered for the award.

Each recipient received $500 awarded by SAGE. NASN (National Association of School Nurses) provides frees registration to the NASN Annual Meeting in San Francisco at which time recipients will receive a certificate from The Journal of School Nursing recognizing their achievement. The Executive Editor and the Editorial Advisory Board recommended that the monetary award be used to defray the expenses incurred to attend the Annual Meeting of the National Association of School Nurses June 23–26, 2012. Acceptance in peer-reviewed journals represents recognition for excellence; however writing awards offer additional recognition and allow us to introduce the authors as the real world people they are.

sec.title: The JOSN-SAGE First Publication Award
sec.p: The JOSN-SAGE First Publication Award recognizes writing excellence of a first-time school nurse author. The selected manuscript is judged on the basis of its contribution to thought and or practice in school nursing and the form and writing clarity of the submission.

Gail Hoxie-Setterstrom, MAN, RN, LSN, is the school nurse receiving the JOSN-SAGE First Publication Award for her publication entitled School Wellness Policies: Opportunity for Change (Hoxie-Setterstrom & Hoglulnd, 2011). Ms. Hoxie-Setterstrom graduated with a baccalaureate in nursing from The College of St. Catherine in St. Paul, Minnesota. Her work experience includes staff nurse positions in orthopedics, kidney transplant, and medical–surgical units before being employed as a maternal–child health public health nurse. In 1987, Ms. Hoxie-Setterstrom began her career as a school nurse at Farmington High School. In 2002, she became the coordinator of health services for this suburban school district of 6,600 students. Ms. Hoxie-Setterstrom completed her master’s degree in nursing leadership from Bethel University, St. Paul, Minnesota. It was during this time that she became interested in quality policy development for the creation of sustainable, environmental changes around healthy nutrition and activity. She was a presenter at the Healthy Schools Conference in 2010 and the Making a Difference Conference in 2012. Ms. Hoxie-Setterstrom is the chairperson for the Farmington Schools Wellness Committee, secretary of the Minnesota Greater Metro Nurses Group, and represents the School Nurses of Minnesota on the Steering Committee of the Minnesota Action for Healthy Kids.
Ms. Hoxie-Setterstrom is married, has six children, and gladly spends her free time with her eight grandchildren.

caption.p: The JOSN-SAGE First Publication Award Winner: Gail Hoxie-Setterstrom MAN, RN, LSN

sec.title: The JOSN-SAGE Scholarly Writing Award
sec.p: The JOSN-SAGE Scholarly Writing Award recognizes excellence in writing and contributions to school nursing. The winning manuscript contributes to School Nursing by providing research results, evidence for practice or policy development or a major review of research literature that significantly influences school health policy, improves school nursing practice, or contributes to school health administration and collaboration.

Suzan J. Song, MD, MPH, is the winner of The JOSN-SAGE Scholarly Writing Award for her manuscript entitled Asian Student Depression in American High Schools: Differences in Risk Factors (Song, Ziegler, Arsenault, Fried, & Hacker, 2011). Dr. Song is a child and adolescent psychiatrist. Her education in cultural awareness began as a daughter of Korean immigrants. After formal studies in college (BS dual major: Biology and Epistemology across Cultures and a French focus at the University of Michigan), she lived in a Zulu village of KwaZulu/Natal, South Africa during the peak of the HIV/AIDS period in 2000. Impressed by the sociocultural, political, and economic effects on health, she then pursued diverse training in medicine (MD from the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine), public health and policy (MPH from the Harvard School of Public Health), adult psychiatry training (Harvard Longwood), child/adolescent psychiatry (Stanford), family therapy and parent–infant psychotherapy training for traumatized families (University of California San Francisco). Currently, she is pursuing research, as a postdoctoral fellow at the Stanford/Sierra Pacific Veterans’ Affairs Mental Illness Research, Education, and Clinical Care program, with current grants on the intergenerational effects of violence on child mental health.

caption.p: The JOSN-SAGE Scholarly Writing Award Winner: Suzan J. Song MD, MPH

sec.p: Advocating on behalf of the Asian and Asian American community, she worked on behalf of domestically abused Asian immigrant women in New York, via a George Soros Community Health Fellowship. Understanding the close intersection of mental health, violence, and policy, she also served as a White House Asian Pacific Islander American fellow. With attention to the diverse and unique needs of Asian Americans, Dr. Song continues advocacy work through clinical practice as the medical director and child/adolescent and adult psychiatrist for Asian Americans for Community Involvement, a nonprofit community mental health service. The clinic also has a Center for Survivors of Torture, which serves diverse community health needs for refugees and individuals seeking asylum, many of whom are from Asian countries.

Dr. Song’s interest in psychiatric nursing and Asian communities began with her mother, who immigrated from South Korea to America in 1970 and trained as an advanced practice nurse in psychiatry. Currently, Dr. Song’s home base is in the Bay Area of California, as well as working part-time in Africa. She enjoys hiking, rock climbing, and yoga, in addition to supporting local community projects at home and afar.]
Julia Muennich Cowell, PhD, RNC, FAAN

p.italic: Executive Editor, The Journal of School Nursing
